Package edu.osu.cse.mmxi.machine.interpreter.instructions

Interface Summary
Instruction  
 

Class Summary
Instruction.ADD Adds two registers and writes to a third.
Instruction.ADDimm Adds a register to an immediate operand and writes to another register.
Instruction.AND Takes the bitwise AND of two registers and writes to a third.
Instruction.ANDimm Takes the bitwise AND of a register with an immediate operand and writes to another register.
Instruction.BRx Conditionally branches to a given immediate address on the current page, depending on the condition codes.
Instruction.DBUG The debug command takes no arguments (its instruction format is 1000xxxxxxxxxxxx, with x = don't care), and it just prints out the contents of the 8 registers, the PC, and the FLAGS register.
Instruction.JSR The JMP/JSR command performs an unconditional branch to the given page offset in the current page.
Instruction.JSRR The JMPR/JSRR command performs an unconditional branch to an address, given as the value of a given register plus an unsigned 6-bit index.
Instruction.LD The LD command loads the value of memory at a given page offset into a register.
Instruction.LDI The LDI command retrieves the value of memory at a given page offset, interpreted as an address, and loads the value at this address into a register.
Instruction.LDR The LDR command loads the value of memory at an address calculated as a base register value plus a 6-bit unsigned immediate index into a destination register.
Instruction.LEA The LEA command calculates an address given a page offset and the page number of the PC, and stores it in a register.
Instruction.NOT Sets the destination register to the bitwise-NOT of the source register.
Instruction.RET The RET instruction, designed for use with JSR/JSRR (see Instruction.JSR), sets the PC to the contents of register 7.
Instruction.ST The ST command stores a register to memory at a given page offset.
Instruction.STI The STI command retrieves the value of memory at a given page offset, interpreted as an address, and stores the source register to this address.
Instruction.STR The STR command stores a source register to memory at an address calculated as a base register value plus a 6-bit unsigned immediate index.
Instruction.TRAP The TRAP instruction allows the programmer to call the OS for access to I/O functionality.
